page.title: 02LANGUAGE
page.content: This parish has been essentially Welsh-speaking since originally settled.Towns in the Vale of Clwyd have been Anglicised since they grew up around the castles of the Norman Conquest,but this influence has been negligible in rural areas,especially hilly,where the Feudal System was difficult to apply. Welsh has therefore survived by being closely allied to the hill-farm and owes little to the larger estates nor nearby towns. It may be true to say that the future of the language lies today in the hands of the schools rather than the traditional areas of home and chapel.Clwyd Education Authority operates a Bilingual language policy.
